instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used on non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status?
Output: On non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status,the researchers used visible spectrum and nir spectrum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used on non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status?
Output: Principal component analysis, band autocorrelation, first derivative, second derivative, wavelet transform smoothing, Savitzky-Golay smoothing, and natural logarithm transformation were used as spectral feature processing methods on non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance on non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance on non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status was Spearman's correlation analysis.

instruction: What were the results of using the light gradient boosting machine (LightGBM) and random forest (RF) models in inverting the Pn and FAPAR values in the research on non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status using hyperspectral data?
Output: The results of using the light gradient boosting machine (LightGBM) model based on the hyperspectral first derivative showed that it could better invert the Pn (net photosynthetic rate) of function-leaves in cotton. On the other hand, the random forest (RF) model based on hyperspectral first derivative was found to be better at inverting the FAPAR (fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation) of the cotton canopy. These findings suggest that these machine learning algorithms, when combined with hyperspectral data, can effectively track and diagnose the nitrogen status and growth of cotton in large farms.

instruction: Can the LightGBM model based on hyperspectral first derivative and the RF model based on hyperspectral first derivative be considered superior to traditional methods for non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status, based on the research findings?
Output: Yes, based on the research findings, the LightGBM model based on hyperspectral first derivative and the RF model based on hyperspectral first derivative can be considered superior to traditional methods for non-destructive tracking of cotton nitrogen status. These models showed better performance in inverting the net photosynthetic rate (Pn) and the fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (FAPAR) in cotton compared to other machine learning algorithm models and hyperspectral transformations. Therefore, these advanced metrics derived from the LightGBM and RF models can be used to diagnose nitrogen nutrition and cotton growth status in large farms more effectively than traditional methods.
